CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 9, 1958, page 1, reads: "'No Trouble at Bethany!' - With well placed oratory, Atty. Oliver Jackson, moderator and master for Common Pleas Court, second from right, tells leaders of both factions before start of voting at court-regulated church election meeting at Bethany Baptist Church that the court will not tolerate disorder. There was no hint of any. Left to right: Atty.Thomas Cauley, for anti-McFadden group; the Rev. Clarence McFadden, back to camera; Attorney Johnson and Deacon Thomas H. Lee, leader of anti-McFadden group. After opening with hymn singing, Bible reading and prayer, Bethany Church members voted on printed ballots."
TitMainTitle: Men, including Atty. Thomas Cauley, Rev. Clarence McFadden facing away, Atty. Oliver Jackson or Johnson, and Deacon Thomas H. Lee, gathered in front of stairs for court-regulated church election meeting at Bethany Baptist Church
